name: Everyday Miracles
about: Peer Recovery Support Center for Substance Use and Addiction Support
servicesOffered: Recovery is possible! Walk in, call or visit website for Recovery Support by Peers and professionals.
additionalInfo: Adults | There are many different types of drug detox centers. Specialty services will be listed alongside each drug detox. Some important specialty characteristics to take note of include dual diagnosis, pregnancy detox care, adolescent detox, LGBTQ sensitive, legal referral programs, spanish speaking programs, and detoxes that specialize in co-occurring health issues such as HIV/AIDS. The best fit will depend mostly on what one’s particular needs may be. | Call 774-670-4428 or visit website www.everydaymiraclesprsc.com
serviceDomains: Substance Use & Recovery
populationsServed: Adults; Families

name: Advocates (formerly Family Continuity)
about: Public safety partnership focusing on reducing unnecessary and harmful use of secure detention for low-risk juveniles. Our mission is to safely support youth in the Commonwealth, in their communities, with proper supervision, so that we may reduce the percentage of youth held in detention while their court cases are pending.
servicesOffered: Mental Health: Addiction Recovery, Care Management, Community Behavioral Health Center, Counseling & Psychiatry, Deaf Services, Mental Health Services, Mobile Crisis Intervention, NeuroStar Therapy, Open Dialogue, Peer Support, Pharmacy Services, Residential Services, Youth & Family Counseling; Developmental: Adult Family Care, Day & Employment Services, Developmental Services, Independent Living, Person-Centered Services, Prader-Willi Syndrome Services, Shared Living; Brain Injury: Brain Injury Services; Family Support: Elder Services, Family & Caregiver Services, Family Support Centers, Respite Options; Autism Support: Autism Day Services, Autism Services, Children's ABA Services; Addiction Recovery & Community Justice: Community Justice, Jail Diversion Services
additionalInfo: Referral Process
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Substance use & recovery; Disability & accessibility support
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Adults; Families; Individuals with disabilities
geographicOffices: Framingham; Harvard; Lawrence; Marlborough; Peabody; Plymouth; Waltham; Whitinsville; Worcester

name: Clinical & Support Options (CSO)
about: Nonprofit community behavioral health agency serving Western MA and North Quabbin. Founded 1954 as Franklin County Mental Health Association. Trauma-informed agency providing comprehensive, holistic care. Serves 18,000+ individuals and families annually across 5 counties. "Open Access" model with walk-in availability and "No Wrong Door" coordinated entry.
servicesOffered: Crisis & Emergency Services (24/7/365): Mobile crisis intervention, assessment, stabilization, Community Crisis Stabilization residences; Outpatient Mental Health: Therapy for children/adolescents/adults, diagnostic evaluations, psychiatry, medication management, sexual abuse/trauma treatment, depression/anxiety/PTSD treatment, group therapy, intensive outpatient programs; Family Support Programs: In-home therapy, therapeutic mentoring, Family Resource Centers, Intensive Care Coordination (ICC); Substance Use: Structured outpatient addiction programs; Community-Based Programs: All Stars youth program, STOPLIFT; Shelter, Housing & Homelessness: Friends of the Homeless (FOH)
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Substance use & recovery
accessMethods: Walk-in; Phone request; Emergency / crisis access
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Adults; Families
geographicOffices: Northampton (HQ); Springfield; Amherst; Greenfield; Athol; Pittsfield; Gardner

name: Field of Dreams therapy Farm, LLC
about: Equine-assisted therapy practice working with rescued horses. Founded by Laurie Drazek, LCSW, MSW, M.Ed. (Boston College 2001). Farm opened 2021 on 21-acre property. Works with rescued horses that have experienced trauma to help humans dealing with similar issues. "Every person has a story, every horse has a story."
servicesOffered: One-on-one equine-assisted therapy; Treatment for anxiety, depression, grief, trauma, life transitions/life skills; Group programs for individuals with disabilities (partnership with Seven Hills Foundation); Farmwork activities
additionalInfo: Private residence - appointments only. Located off Route 122 on the Paxton/Rutland line. Horses are highly empathetic and sense trauma/anxiety in humans.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & Mental Health
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Adults; Individuals with disabilities

name: Foster Care Essentials
about: Founded February 2022 by Sharon Bryant (former foster child) and Melissa Mercon Smith. Provides essentials at no charge to foster and kinship care families in Central Massachusetts. Motto: "If we have it, you can have it. If we don't have it, we'll get it."
servicesOffered: Free clothing; Toys; Baby gear; Sports gear; Diapers; Backpacks; School supplies; Personal hygiene products; Summer Footwear Gift Card Giveaway; Fill-A-Backpack Event (back to school)
additionalInfo: Open every other Saturday for families to stop by. Can also schedule appointment to visit location. Events held throughout the year. Bio children in the home are included at events.
serviceDomains: Clothing & basic needs
populationsServed: Young children; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Fostering Change, Inc.
about: We provide foster kids the resources to succeed and the experiences of being a kid.
servicesOffered: Sponsors various gift, clothing, and needs events throughout the year in the Leominster area.
serviceDomains: Clothing & basic needs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Foster / kinship families

name: Family Resource Center
about: Statewide network of community-based centers helping families resolve challenges, strengthen bonds, connect to services, and engage in communities. FRCs serve families with children ages 0-18.
servicesOffered: Family Support: Parent education, Support groups, Crisis response; Education: School services, GED assistance, Special education resources, ESL; Healthcare & Mental Health: Mental health referrals, Substance use support; Basic Needs: Child care referrals, Housing assistance, Financial literacy; Legal: Juvenile court services; Career: Employment assistance; Community: Civic engagement, LGBTQ+ support, Peer support
additionalInfo: 33 locations across all 14 MA counties - see frcma.org/locations for nearest center. Services are free. Interpretation available in 140+ languages via Mass 2-1-1. Funded by MA EOHHS and DCF. Administered by ForHealth Consulting at UMass Chan Medical School. Established 2012 via Chapter 240 (FACES Act).
serviceDomains: Parenting & family support; Healthcare & mental health; Education & youth programs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Adults; Families
geographicOffices: Amherst; Athol; Attleboro; Boston; Brockton; Chelsea; Everett; Fall River; Fitchburg; Framingham; Gardner; Great Barrington; Greenfield; Holyoke; Hyannis; Lawrence; Lowell; Lynn; Nantucket; New Bedford; North Adams; Oak Bluffs; Pittsfield; Plymouth; Quincy; Salem; Southbridge; Springfield; Taunton; Ware; Westfield; Worcester

name: Girls, Inc. of Worcester
about: Girls Inc. of Worcester offers in-person programming for girls in grades K–12 that supports social-emotional learning, education, and positive peer and adult relationships. It can be a stabilizing community resource for girls who benefit from structured, gender-responsive support outside the home.
servicesOffered: Youth Development: After-school programs, Summer programs, School-based programs; STEM: Science, technology, engineering, math education; Life Skills: Economic literacy, Media literacy, Health and fitness; Prevention: Sexual health education, Violence prevention, Drug abuse prevention; Recreation: Swim lessons, Basketball, Sports
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents

name: Griptape
about: We give youth who are seeking access to resources and opportunities the support, respect, and authority to pursue learning in their own way.
servicesOffered: Education: Self-directed 10-week learning projects; Financial: Up to $500 funding for youth projects; Mentorship: Champion mentor support
additionalInfo: GripTape is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that offers young people ages 14–19 total control to design a 10-week learning experience, funding to pursue this learning, and a Champion to support them. | If you’re 14–19, have an interest or passion you want to pursue, and need resources to do it, apply for the GripTape Learning Challenge. | Online Form
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Financial assistance
populationsServed: Adolescents; Transition-age youth

name: The Grow School (SWCEC)
about: DESE-approved public therapeutic day school serving students grades K-12 with communication, developmental, emotional, health, intellectual, neurological, or specific learning disabilities. Part of Southern Worcester County Educational Collaborative (SWCEC).
servicesOffered: Education: Therapeutic day school (K-12), Special education, Vocational training; Therapy: Counseling, Speech therapy, Occupational therapy, Physical therapy, ABA (Applied Behavior Analysis); Support: Adaptive PE, Vision services, Hearing services; Programs: RISE Academy (general ed alternative), Assessment Program, Career Development Program
additionalInfo: 180-day school year plus 25-day summer program. Students ages 3-22. Referrals through school district TEAM process. Two campuses: Elementary (Southbridge) and Middle/High (Dudley). Established 1975.
serviceDomains: Education & Youth Programs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Individuals with disabilities

name: Individualized Education Program (IEP)
about: Massachusetts DESE resource page for the Individualized Education Program (IEP), a written document outlining educational goals and services for students with disabilities ages 3-22. Includes forms, guides, and parent resources for the special education process.
servicesOffered: Information & Resources: IEP forms, Technical guides, Parent information guides, Transition planning resources, Quick reference guides; Translations: Forms available in 15+ languages including Spanish, Portuguese, Chinese, Arabic, Haitian Creole
additionalInfo: New IEP form implemented Fall 2024. IEP process is administered through local school districts. For advocacy support, contact Federation for Children with Special Needs (FCSN) or Massachusetts Advocates for Children.
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Disability & accessibility support
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Families; Individuals with disabilities

name: Inner Voice Outer Change for Youth (IVOC)
about: IVOC provides therapeutic services that foster youth empowerment through the creation of music and multimedia projects. Their approach encourages marginalized youth to partner with IVOC as they lean into the therapeutic process of self-expression.
servicesOffered: Healthcare & Mental Health: Therapeutic services, Creative wellness programs; Education & Youth Programs: After-school music programs, Videography training, Multimedia arts; Community: Upstream Initiative (academic success rewards with self-care access)
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Education & youth programs
populationsServed: Adolescents; Transition-age youth

name: Kid's Net (MSPCC)
about: Kid's Net is a program of MSPCC (Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, a division of Eliot Community Human Services) that provides services and supports to DCF foster, pre-adoptive, and kinship families statewide.
servicesOffered: Foster Care Support: Family Resource Liaisons (experienced foster/adoptive parents providing mentoring); Respite: Up to 10 nights/year paid overnight respite, 10 hours/month babysitting; Training: CPR/First Aid, foster care-specific trainings, online training library; Support Groups: Regional support groups for foster families; After-Hours Helpline: Evening/weekend support when DCF offices closed
additionalInfo: All services free for foster parents. Kid's Net contracts with DCF to provide statewide support. Family Resource Liaisons available in every DCF area office. Also operates KINnections program for kinship caregivers.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare; Parenting & family support
populationsServed: Families; Foster / Kinship Families
geographicOffices: Lexington; Boston; Holyoke; Lawrence; Lowell; Worcester; Hyannis

name: Kind Hearts for Kids
about: Serves vulnerable children and teens living in foster, adoptive, and kinship care including grandparents raising grandchildren. We're dedicated to being a compassionate, supportive, and positive influence on these children by honoring and celebrating them on their birthdays & holidays. We are committed to providing fun events to shower them with kindness, and help build confidence and self respect. We engage and bring awareness to their needs through fundraising, spreading our group’s important message and engaging in service projects in our local community.
servicesOffered: Community & Mutual Aid: Birthday bags, Birthday parties (ages 3-18), Holiday celebrations; Events: Fun events for foster/kinship youth; Programs: Creative art sessions for self-esteem and emotional regulation
additionalInfo: Founded 2019 by Nicole Mitchell. Operates the Kind-Nest, a safe haven space in Pocasset. Mailing address: 5 Sea Lane, Sagamore Beach, MA 02562. Serves Cape Cod, Plymouth, Wareham, and throughout MA.
serviceDomains: Community & mutual aid; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Kinship Legal Toolkit
about: Legal resource toolkit from the ABA Children's Rights Litigation Committee providing social science research and legal advocacy tools to support kinship placements in child welfare cases.
servicesOffered: Information & Resources: Research summaries on benefits of kinship care, Legal advocacy tools, Citations to laws and policies, Social science research for court use
additionalInfo: Created by ABA Litigation Section Children's Rights Litigation Committee with contributions from MA Committee for Public Counsel Services. Updated January 2022. See also grandfamilies.org for state-specific kinship laws database.
serviceDomains: Legal aid & advocacy
populationsServed: Adults; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Kinship Navigator
about: Kinship Navigator is a program of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts that assists all kinship caregivers (grandparents and other relatives) with accessing services for themselves and the children they are raising.
servicesOffered: Navigation & Referral: DTA benefits navigation, WIC assistance, DCF guidance; Support Services: Family Resource Center connections, support groups, mental health/counseling referrals, legal services referrals, childcare assistance, substance misuse family support; Information: Food & nutrition assistance, community resources
additionalInfo: Serves DCF kinship foster parents, Probate & Family Court involved families, and informal caregivers. Zoom support available. Spanish language resources available.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare; Parenting & family support
populationsServed: Young children; Adults; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Legendary Legacies Inc.
about: Gang rehabilitation and reentry nonprofit serving young men of color ages 17-24 in Worcester. Founded 2018 by Ron Waddell. Based on four pillars: belief, opportunity, transformation, and brotherhood.
servicesOffered: Mentoring & Life Skills: Case management, positive male role models, life skills development, family support services; Programs: Legacy Builders (at-risk youth prevention), Legacy Links (reentry from incarceration), Legacy Transport (workforce development/food distribution), Crisis Response Team, Restorative Justice Circles; Other: Athletics, podcasting, recreational opportunities, local/national/international service opportunities
additionalInfo: Partners with MA DYS, Worcester Public Schools, Worcester County Sheriff's Office, Worcester House of Corrections, Worcester County Food Bank. Faith-inspired program. EIN: 82-4456424
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Employment & job training
populationsServed: Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Justice-involved individuals

name: Love Your Labels
about: LGBTQ+ led nonprofit that supports queer and trans youth through art, fashion, and design. Founded 2019 in Worcester. Believes authentic self-expression is life-saving.
servicesOffered: Youth Programs: Threads fashion design and identity program (middle/high school), Youth Fashion Designer-in-Residence program; Community Programs: Drag Queen Story Time, Open Studio Thursdays (3-9pm fashion/design makerspace), ASL Meetup Group for Deaf Queer community, Transgender Day of Remembrance events; Family Support: Parents & Families Network for caregivers of LGBTQ+ youth; Events: Queer AF Art+Fashion Show (annual fundraiser at Mechanics Hall); Advocacy: Queer Coalition of Greater Worcester (fiscally sponsored initiative)
additionalInfo: Has Creative Community Room & Sewing Studio space in Worcester. For Parents & Families Network contact dani@loveyourlabels.org
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Community & mutual aid
populationsServed: Adolescents; Transition-age youth

name: LUK Crisis Center
about: Nonprofit social service agency founded 1970 in Fitchburg (originally "Let Us Know Crisis Center"). Provides prevention, intervention, education, and support services for youth, families, and adults throughout Central Massachusetts.
servicesOffered: Mentoring: Community-based and site-based mentoring for youth ages 6-17; Behavioral Health: Mental health assessment and treatment, individual/family/couples therapy, expressive art therapy, psychiatric consultation, medication management; Substance Use: Prevention programs, outpatient treatment, Moving On Program (MET/CBT), CLYR recovery support, CRAFT parent support groups; Trauma: Central MA Child Trauma Center (TF-CBT, CPP, ARC); Residential: Horizon House (ages 10-18), Bridge Home (up to age 12); Youth Development: Prevention programming, youth groups
additionalInfo: Referrals: referrals@luk.org or www.luk.org/make-a-referral. Youth under 18 need parental/guardian consent. Spanish & Portuguese capacity for some programs. CEO: Beth Barto. Founded 1970.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Substance use & recovery; Education & youth programs
accessMethods: Self-referral; Phone request; Emergency / crisis access
populationsServed: Adolescents; Adults; Families

name: Massachusetts Adoption Resource Exchange (MARE)
about: Private nonprofit founded 1957 to find adoptive homes for children and teens in foster care, including sibling groups and children who are traditionally harder to place. One of the first five adoption exchanges in the US. Partners with MA DCF and private adoption agencies. Has helped place over 7,000 children since founding.
servicesOffered: Adoption Services: Recruitment of adoptive families, family education and training, adoption support services, targeted recruitment for specific waiting children; Programs: Wendy's Wonderful Kids (child-focused recruitment for longest-waiting youth), Weekend Family Connections (host family program), adoption events statewide; Support: Connects prospective families with social workers, provides resources throughout adoption process
additionalInfo: All services free to families. Executive Director: Lisa Funaro, MSW. Open to all family types regardless of race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender identity, or background. Currently ~1,150 MA children with goal of adoption but no identified resource.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Families

name: Massachusetts Alliance for Foster Families (MAFF)
about: Statewide association of DCF foster, adoptive, kinship, and guardianship parents providing advocacy and support for children and the families who care for them. Supported by MSPCC (Massachusetts Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children). Board meets regularly to identify issues of concern and advance solutions.
servicesOffered: Advocacy: Legislative advocacy for foster/kinship/adoptive family rights, Foster Parents' Bill of Rights information; Support: Connection to MSPCC Kid's Net resources, annual foster care conferences, area representative network; Education: Information on rights and DCF processes
additionalInfo: Free membership open to all foster, kinship, adoptive, and guardianship parents. Operates under MSPCC, a division of Eliot Community Human Services. Helped establish MA Foster Parents' Bill of Rights.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare; Legal aid & advocacy
populationsServed: Young children; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Massachusetts Behavioral Health Help Line
about: The Massachusetts Behavioral Health Help Line (BHHL) is here to connect you directly to clinical help, when and where you need it. Even if you’re not sure what kind of help or treatment you may need, we can help guide you.
servicesOffered: Crisis Support: 24/7/365 call, text, or online chat; Clinical assessment and triage; Connection to mental health and substance use treatment (outpatient, urgent, crisis); Warm handoffs to services; 48-hour follow-up for urgent referrals; Resource referrals for transportation, childcare, food
additionalInfo: No health insurance required.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & Mental Health
accessMethods: Self-referral; Phone request; Online request; Emergency / crisis access
populationsServed: Adolescents; Adults; Families

name: Massachusetts Victims of Violent Crime Compensation
about: Financial assistance program for eligible victims of violent crime, covering uninsured medical/dental care, mental health counseling, funeral/burial costs, lost wages, and other crime-related expenses up to $25,000. Funds of last resort obtained primarily from perpetrators.
servicesOffered: Financial Assistance: Medical and dental care, mental health counseling (including alternative therapies like trauma-informed yoga, therapeutic horseback riding, acupuncture), funeral and burial costs, lost wages, security measures; Sexual Assault: Forensic exam costs automatically covered; Applications available in English and Spanish
additionalInfo: Crime must be reported to police within 5 days. Application deadline 3 years from crime. Approved claims never expire. General inquiries: MOVA@mass.gov
serviceDomains: Financial Assistance
populationsServed: Adults; Families; Survivors of domestic violence

name: Montachusett Regional Vocational Technical High School Care Solace
about: Mental health care coordination service provided to Monty Tech students, families, and staff at no cost. Care Solace navigates the mental health system to find community-based providers and secure appointments.
servicesOffered: Care Navigation: Finding mental health providers matched to specific needs, appointment booking, follow-up to ensure satisfaction; Features: 24/7/365 support including holidays/weekends, 200+ languages, accepts public/private insurance or sliding scale options, text and video chat available
additionalInfo: Must be Monty Tech student, family member, or staff. Ashburnham, Ashby, Athol, Barre, Fitchburg, Gardner, Harvard, Holden, Hubbardston, Lunenburg, Petersham, Phillipston, Princeton, Royalston, Sterling, Templeton, Westminster, Winchendon
serviceDomains: Healthcare & Mental Health; Substance Use & Recovery
populationsServed: Adolescents; Adults; Families

name: My Ombudsman
about: Independent advocacy program helping MassHealth members understand their healthcare rights and benefits to access needed care. Operated by Disability Policy Consortium (DPC) through contract with MassHealth. Serves members of all ages, abilities, and identities.
servicesOffered: Advocacy: Answer questions about MassHealth plan benefits and rights, explain denial letters, help address access problems, mediate between members/providers/plans; Support: Investigate complaints, explain grievance and appeal processes, referrals to other organizations; Walk-in: Boston office appointments Thursdays 10am-3pm
additionalInfo: Hours: Monday-Friday 9am-4pm. Wheelchair accessible office. Cannot represent members in appeals/grievances but can explain the process. "No wrong door" approach. Serves all MassHealth plan types including One Care, Fee for Service, ACOs, MCOs, and Children's Medical Security Plan.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Legal aid & advocacy
populationsServed: Adults; Families; Individuals with disabilities

name: Net of Compassion
about: Faith-based nonprofit founded 2010 by Pastor Richie Gonzalez following his own recovery from substance use disorder and homelessness.
servicesOffered: We serve men and women struggling with poverty, substance use disorder, prostitution, homelessness and those living with mental illness.
additionalInfo: Joshua's Showers at St. John's Church, 44 Temple St. Hotel Grace at Ascension Church, 44 Vernon St. Programs at 674 Main St (basement level). Volunteer-driven, peer-led model.
serviceDomains: Housing & shelter; Substance use & recovery; Food & nutrition
populationsServed: Adults; Low-income / housing-insecure individuals

name: New Hope, Inc.
about: Domestic and sexual violence services for 41 communities in South-Central and Southeastern Massachusetts. 24/7 hotline, emergency shelter, counseling, court advocacy, and prevention programs. All services free.
servicesOffered: Crisis: 24/7 hotline, emergency shelter (2 confidential locations); Counseling: Individual/family for adults and children, EMDR, TF-CBT, ARC; Court: SAFEPLAN advocates at 7 district courts and 1 probate court (Attleboro, Dudley, East Brookfield, Milford, Taunton, Westborough, Uxbridge); Other: Supervised visitation (Worcester), housing stabilization, civilian police advocates, SANE advocates at Morton & Sturdy hospitals, RESPECT intimate partner abuse education program
serviceDomains: Domestic Violence & Safety
populationsServed: Young children; Adults; Survivors of Domestic Violence

name: One Can Help
about: Provides emergency funding for at-risk youth and families involved with DCF or juvenile courts. Resources include transportation, housing assistance, education, basic necessities, and activities. Funding up to $1,000 per request.
servicesOffered: Emergency resource funding: transportation (bus/train passes, car repair), housing (emergency rent, utilities, security deposits, furniture), education (laptops, school supplies, job training), basic necessities (clothing, food cards, baby supplies), activities (camps, sports), other (ID cards, therapeutic needs, visitation support)
additionalInfo: Applications accepted only from professionals (attorneys, social workers, CASA, child advocates). Text preferred for contact. Response by next business day. Cannot reimburse cash or expenses prior to approval.
serviceDomains: Financial assistance; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Transition-Age Youth; Adults; Families; Foster / Kinship Families; Individuals with Disabilities

name: Open Sky Community Services
about: Large human services agency serving adults and families with mental health challenges, developmental disabilities, autism, brain injuries, substance use disorders, and homelessness. Offers 100+ programs across Central Massachusetts. Referrals through DDS (for autism/I/DD) or DMH (for behavioral health).
servicesOffered: Autism/I/DD: autism individual supports (case management, life skills, employment coaching), family support center, day habilitation, residential services, shared living, adult family care; Behavioral health: residential, outpatient, clubhouse (Crystal House in Gardner), youth/young adult services, LGBTQ+ youth (Safe Homes); Other: brain injury services, housing/homelessness services, substance use disorders, Rapid Response HUB (urgent behavioral health), Bridge Training Institute (professional training)
additionalInfo: DDS referral required for autism/I/DD services. DMH referral for behavioral health. Family Support Center serves Blackstone Valley communities. Deaf/hard of hearing program available.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Disability & accessibility support; Housing & shelter
populationsServed: Adults; Families; Individuals with disabilities; Low-income / housing-insecure individuals

name: Parent/Professional Advocacy League (PPAL)
about: Statewide family organization advocating for improved access to mental health services for children, youth, and families. Provides parent support groups, youth groups, professional training, and policy advocacy.
servicesOffered: Parent support groups, youth support groups (HOPE for ages 13-18, YAYA for young adults), family support specialists, professional training/workshops, advocacy, free webinars and resources
additionalInfo: Free services. No referral or insurance needed. Free dinner provided at most support groups. Limited childcare available with registration.
serviceDomains: Healthcare & Mental Health
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Adults; Families

name: Planting the Seed
about: Collects and distributes toys, school supplies, and winter clothing to families in need in Worcester. Works through partner social service agencies.
servicesOffered: Holiday gifts for children, school supplies and backpacks, winter clothing
additionalInfo: Does not accept individual assistance requests. Resources distributed through partner agencies (contact your DCF worker or shelter case manager). Annual drives: Holiday Toy Drive (December at Worcester Fitness), Stuff the Bus (August, donation bins at fire stations).
serviceDomains: Clothing & basic needs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Families; Low-income / housing-insecure individuals

name: Plummer Youth Promise
about: Provides permanency services for youth in foster care including permanency mediation, intensive permanency services, residential programs, and foster parent recruitment. Serves about 300 youth annually statewide.
servicesOffered: Permanency mediation (alternative to contested court proceedings for care/protection, guardianship, TPR cases); Intensive Permanency Services (for youth ages 0-20 with barriers to permanency); Prevention services (to prevent removal); Residential programs (group home, supported apartments, community apartments for ages 18-22); Foster parent program
additionalInfo: Permanency mediation referrals through Juvenile Court or Probate & Family Court. Intensive Permanency Services referrals through DCF (IPS@plummeryouthpromise.org). Community Apartments: lease transfers to youth at discharge; $5,000 for deposits/furniture provided.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Quinsigamond Community College
about: Public community college offering 100+ degree/certificate programs. Provides DCF Tuition Waiver for foster youth, MassEducate (free tuition for MA residents without bachelor's degree), mentoring, emergency grants, and wraparound student support.
servicesOffered: DCF Tuition Waiver (free tuition for foster youth in state custody); MassEducate (free community college); Mentoring program (monthly 1:1 meetings with staff/faculty/professionals); SUCCESS Scholars (case-management advising); Emergency Assistance Grants (tuition, books, housing, food, childcare); Food Pantry; Parenting Student Support Services; Children's School (on-site childcare)
additionalInfo: DCF Tuition Waiver requires DCF letter confirming eligibility. MassEducate requires FAFSA completion. Mentoring: complete application at qccmentoring.xinspire.com, then phone interview. Emergency grants: email emergencygrant@qcc.mass.edu.
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Financial assistance
populationsServed: Transition-age youth; Adults; Foster / kinship families

name: Rise Above Foundation
about: Funds enrichment activities for youth in DCF custody, including those in foster care, group homes, residential placements, and independent living. Also serves young adults 18+ who have voluntarily signed with DCF.
servicesOffered: Funding for: sports (league fees, equipment, uniforms), music/art lessons and instruments, dance/martial arts/gymnastics, computers and electronics, specialty summer camps (1-2 weeks), prom expenses, graduation clothes, class trips, concert/event tickets, theme parks, religious/cultural celebrations (Quinceañera, Bar/Bat Mitzvah), post-secondary education, apartment set-ups for aging out youth
additionalInfo: Does NOT fund: general day camps, daycare/preschool, therapy/counseling, debt relief/utilities, furniture, reimbursements for prior expenses, general clothing. Submit requests 1+ month before funds due. DCF social worker approval required. Applications reviewed on rolling basis. CASA volunteers can apply on behalf of youth.
serviceDomains: Financial assistance; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Foster / kinship families

name: Sibling Connections
about: Provides year-round programming to help siblings separated by foster care maintain and strengthen their relationships. Only MA organization solely devoted to sibling connections for foster youth.
servicesOffered: Camp Sibling Connections (week-long residential camp in August, 100+ kids); Weekend Retreats (full weekends together, up to 30 siblings); Sibling Socials (monthly Sunday afternoon outings October-May in Boston, Lowell, Springfield); Youth Leadership Program (ages 16-20, leadership training, transition to peer leader/counselor roles)
additionalInfo: Ages 7-20. At least two siblings in separate foster/kinship placements (or one adopted). DCF social worker approval required. Anyone can refer but must provide DCF contact. Not a therapeutic program. Transportation provided by volunteers for Socials. Free. Email leslie@siblingconnections.org to start enrollment.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Foster / kinship families

name: Silver Lining Mentoring
about: Mentoring organization in Massachusetts exclusively focused on youth in foster care. Matches youth ages 7+ with trained volunteer mentors who commit to 6-8 hours/month for at least one year. Matches last average 55 months (6x national average). Youth 7x more likely to go to college than peers in foster care.
servicesOffered: Community Based Mentoring (1:1 matches, ages 7+); Learn & Earn (12-week life skills program for ages 16+, employment/financial literacy, matched savings); E-Mentoring (virtual mentoring); Young Adult Services (clinical support, resource brokering, housing support for youth aging out)
additionalInfo: Youth must be involved with DCF and approved for FamilyNet funding. Must live in Greater Boston (within Rt. 128). Youth-driven matching process. Mentors supported by Masters-level clinical staff. Referrals: complete pre-application at silverliningmentoring.org or email intake@silverliningmentoring.org.
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Transition-age youth; Foster / kinship families

name: The Gifted Crate
about: Delivers customized birthday-in-a-box to children and teens involved with DCF throughout Massachusetts, whether they live with biological families, kin, unrelated foster homes, or congregate care programs. Founded fall 2020. Each crate includes boxed cake mix, frosting, candles, plates, napkins, and customized gifts based on the child's interests. Crates valued $50-$100.
servicesOffered: Birthday crates for DCF-involved children (biological family, kin, foster, or congregate care placements); supports foster parents with birthday celebrations
additionalInfo: DCF Social Workers email thegiftedcrate@gmail.com to request birthday crate form. Requests must be submitted 2 weeks prior to delivery date. Organization does NOT accept direct requests from families.
serviceDomains: Foster care & child welfare; Community & mutual aid
populationsServed: Young children; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: The Jason Hayes Foundation
about: Founded 2006 in memory of Jason Hayes. Supports children ages 5-18 who experienced early childhood trauma including abuse, chronic homelessness, substance abuse in home, or foster care placement.
servicesOffered: Camp scholarships (special needs camps for PTSD, behavioral/emotional difficulties); College scholarships (2 or 4 year); Grants to nonprofits serving this population
additionalInfo: Camp scholarship apps reviewed Feb-June (first-come-first-served). Requires letter from therapist/social worker/counselor. Grant proposals accepted Oct 1 - Dec 16. MA residents only.
serviceDomains: Financial assistance; Education & youth programs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Foster / kinship families

name: The Wonderfund (Massachusetts Wonderfund, Inc.)
about: Provides emergency essentials and enrichment opportunities to children involved with MA DCF. Serves kids in foster care, kinship care, pre-adoptive homes, and congregate care statewide.
servicesOffered: Emergency essentials (clothing, PJs, hygiene kits, backpacks); Enrichment grants (camps, sports, music, dance, SAT prep, certifications); Holiday Gift Drive; Wonderfund Access Card (free/discounted admission to museums, YMCAs, attractions); Family Room Renovations at DCF offices
additionalInfo: All resources accessible ONLY through DCF social workers. Access Card mailed to foster homes in December; can request via accesscard@wonderfundma.org. Enrichment funding requires invoice from vendor (no reimbursements).
serviceDomains: Clothing & basic needs; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Foster / kinship families

name: THRIVE
about: Supports youth and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) and their families. Serves Worcester County and Middlesex West regions.
servicesOffered: Community residences; Family Support Center (DDS-funded); Respite (one-on-one and group); Community-Based Day Supports; Flourish Food Pantry; Social/recreational programs (Prom for All Ages, dances, after-school, fitness, sports, vacation camps, field trips, Special Olympics)
serviceDomains: Disability & accessibility support; Parenting & family support
populationsServed: Adolescents; Adults; Families; Individuals with disabilities

name: TriTogether
about: Free virtual tutoring for children in foster care, kinship care, or adopted out of foster care. Sessions held on Zoom, one hour weekly, covering any subject based on student needs.
servicesOffered: Virtual tutoring (all subjects); homework help; test prep; organization skills; LearnTogether resources
additionalInfo: Students matched with tutors based on goals. Sessions are flexible based on student needs.
serviceDomains: Education & Youth Programs
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Foster / kinship families

name: W. S. R. Wellness Coaching
about: Yoga, meditation, breathwork, and wellness coaching focused on individuals in recovery from substance use disorder. Specializes in holistic healing and recovery support.
servicesOffered: Yoga classes; Meditation; Breathwork; Wellness retreats for women in recovery; Personal development classes; BIPOC yoga classes
additionalInfo: Has contract with UMass Memorial's Moms Do Care program for women in recovery. Partners with local nonprofits. Hosts accessible/affordable wellness retreats for women in recovery.
serviceDomains: Substance use & recovery; Healthcare & mental health
populationsServed: Adults

name: Wandering Heart Project
about: Provides basic essentials and clothing to foster and homeless children of all ages throughout Massachusetts. Over 1,000 deliveries made statewide.
servicesOffered: Clothing (newborn to young adult); Toiletries; Baby gear (strollers, play-pens); Backpacks, duffel bags, suitcases; Wander Bags for families in crisis
additionalInfo: Donations accepted in Bridgewater and Rockland, MA. Partners with Brockton WIC office. Cannot accept items with family terms, company logos, or souvenir shirts.
serviceDomains: Clothing & Basic Needs; Community & Mutual Aid
populationsServed: Young children; Families; Foster / Kinship Families; Low-Income / Housing-Insecure Individuals

name: WE'VE GOT YOUR BACKpack
about: These backpacks frequently become more than a place for school supplies. They can also become a lifeline for children being transitioned into foster care, replacing the trash bags that too many children are still asked to stuff their limited possessions into.
additionalInfo: Reach out to Deborah Sweet personally through email, cell, or Facebook messenger on the WGYB Page
serviceDomains: Clothing & basic needs; Foster care & child welfare
populationsServed: Young children; Transition-Age Youth; Families; Foster / Kinship Families

name: Worcester Area Mission Society (WAMS)
about: Works with individuals and community partners to inspire economic and educational equity through social change. Programs focus on youth development, early childhood education, and community drives.
servicesOffered: Summer CUBS (K-6 summer learning program with Clark University); Play Group Plus (early childhood education in Worcester & Fitchburg); ReachOut Worcester (youth immersion program, ages 13+, currently paused); Youth Empowerment Program (YEP!); Migrant support drives (clothing, diapers, personal care); Community drives for coats, books, and other needs
additionalInfo: Building available for community meetings and events. Partners with Worcester Family Partnership, Main South CDC, Boys & Girls Club, Clark University, Woodland Academy. Fiscal sponsor for emerging nonprofits.
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Community & mutual aid
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Families; Immigrants / refugees

name: Worcester County Juvenile Court Clinic
about: Program of UMass Memorial Health - Community Healthlink, operated under agreement with MA Dept. of Mental Health and Trial Court of Massachusetts
servicesOffered: Court-ordered mental health screenings, forensic evaluations, case management, and treatment services for youth in the Juvenile Justice System
additionalInfo: Youth Mobile Crisis Numbers: Worcester 1-866-549-2141 | North Cental Worcester County Team: 1-800-977-5555 | South Central Worcester County Team: 1-800-294-4665
serviceDomains: Healthcare & mental health; Legal aid & advocacy
populationsServed: Young children; Adolescents; Justice-involved individuals

name: Worcester Parent/Caregiver Guide to Community Services
about: Comprehensive printable resource guide for Worcester parents and caregivers, listing local services for families. Currently on 14th edition.
servicesOffered: Listings for: childcare, food assistance, housing, benefits enrollment, youth programs, autism resources, mental health, substance recovery, CORI sealing, and more
additionalInfo: Spanish version available. Created by Worcester Community Connections Coalition of Seven Hills Foundation. Also hosted at communityhelp.net and wcac.net
serviceDomains: Community & Mutual Aid
populationsServed: Families

name: Worcester Youth Center
about: Safe haven providing educational, recreational, and social opportunities for youth. Only no-cost drop-in program in Worcester for ages 14-24.
servicesOffered: GED/ESL preparation (bilingual), paid summer internships, computer lab, in-house counseling, recording studio, culinary program, film enrichment, health/wellness programming, recreation (pool, basketball, video games), Teen Cafe
additionalInfo: Free membership. Walk-in for ages 14-17; ages 18-24 by appointment only. Parent/guardian signature required for under 18. Healthy snacks/meals provided. Contact: ncolon@worcesteryouthcenter.org
serviceDomains: Education & youth programs; Employment & job training
populationsServed: Adolescents; Transition-age youth

name: SNAP (Department of Transitional Assistance)
about: Federal nutrition program administered by MA Department of Transitional Assistance (DTA) providing monthly food benefits via EBT card. Formerly known as food stamps.
servicesOffered: Monthly food benefits on EBT card; Healthy Incentives Program (HIP) for extra fruits/vegetables at farmers markets ($40-$80/month based on household size); SNAP Path to Work job training; connections to utility discounts, free school meals, museum discounts via EBT Card to Culture
additionalInfo: Apply online at DTA Connect, by phone, in person at local DTA office, or by mail. Decision within 30 days; emergency/expedited SNAP within 7 days for qualifying households. Applications available in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Khmer, Vietnamese, Haitian Creole, Russian, Chinese, French, Italian, Korean, Polish, and Arabic.
serviceDomains: Food & Nutrition
populationsServed: Adults; Families; Low-income / housing-insecure individuals
geographicOffices: Boston; Brockton; Chelsea; Fall River; Fitchburg; Framingham; Greenfield; Holyoke; Hyannis; Lawrence; Lowell; Lynn; Malden; New Bedford; North Adams; Pittsfield; Plymouth; Quincy; Revere; Salem; Southbridge; Springfield; Taunton; Worcester

name: WIC (Department of Transitional Assistance)
about: Federal nutrition program providing healthy foods, nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and referrals to healthcare and other services for pregnant/breastfeeding women and children under 5.
servicesOffered: Supplemental healthy foods (via WIC card/EBT); nutrition education; breastfeeding support and peer counseling; health care referrals; immunization screening; referrals to childcare, housing, fuel assistance
additionalInfo: Available regardless of immigration or citizenship status. Not included in public charge rule. Foster parents, grandparents, and legal guardians can apply for children under 5. Automatic eligibility if receiving MassHealth/Medicaid, SNAP, or TAFDC.
serviceDomains: Food & Nutrition; Parenting & Family Support
populationsServed: Infants and toddlers; Young children; Adults; Families
eligibilityConstraints: Age restrictions; Income-based eligibility; Residency requirements
geographicOffices: Boston; Brockton; Chelsea; Fall River; Fitchburg; Framingham; Greenfield; Holyoke; Hyannis; Lawrence; Lowell; Lynn; Malden; New Bedford; North Adams; Pittsfield; Plymouth; Quincy; Revere; Salem; Southbridge; Springfield; Taunton; Worcester
